natural problem: I need to learn vocabulary words for my Spanish exam. There are 500 words and the exam grade is the percentage of these words that I recall correctly. Assuming I will recall correctly the words I learn and assuming my guesses will not yield any points, what is the least number of words I should learn to get at least $85\%$ on the exam?
natural solution: Since the exam grade is the percentage of words I recall correctly, we can set up a proportion to find the minimum number of words I need to learn: \begin{align} \frac{\text{number of words I need to learn}}{\text{total words}}&=\frac{85\%}{100\%}\\

\frac{x}{500}&=\frac{85}{100}\\ x&=\frac{85}{100}\cdot 500\\ x&=85\cdot 5\\ x&=\boxed{425}. \end{align}Learning 425 words will lead to a score of exactly $85\%$, so I do not need to learn any more words than 425.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_words learned_words :: real
assumes h0 : "total_words = 500"
and h1 : "learned_words / total_words \<ge> 0.85"
shows  "learned_words \<ge> 425"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I need to learn vocabulary words for my Spanish exam. There are 500 words and the exam grade is the percentage of these words that I recall correctly. Assuming I will recall correctly the words I learn and assuming my guesses will not yield any points, what is the least number of words I should learn to get at least $85\%$ on the exam? The final Answer is 425
 ### Proof
 Since the exam grade is the percentage of words I recall correctly, we can set up a proportion to find the minimum number of words I need to learn: \begin{align} \frac{\text{number of words I need to learn}}{\text{total words}}&=\frac{85\%}{100\%}\\
 \frac{x}{500}&=\frac{85}{100}\\ x&=\frac{85}{100}\cdot 500\\ x&=85\cdot 5\\ x&=\boxed{425}. \end{align}Learning 425 words will lead to a score of exactly $85\%$, so I do not need to learn any more words than 425.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_words learned_words :: real
assumes h0 : "total_words = 500"
and h1 : "learned_words / total_words \<ge> 0.85"
shows  "learned_words \<ge> 425"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: "If the total number of words is 500 and the ratio of learned words to the total number of words is at least 0.85, how many words have been learned at minimum? The final answer is 425."

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_words :: real and recall_percentage :: real and exam_grade :: real
assumes h0 : "total_words = 500"
and h1 : "recall_percentage = 0.85"
and h2 : "exam_grade = total_words * recall_percentage"
shows  "exam_grade >= 425"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I need to learn vocabulary words for my Spanish exam. There are 500 words and the exam grade is the percentage of these words that I recall correctly. Assuming I will recall correctly the words I learn and assuming my guesses will not yield any points, what is the least number of words I should learn to get at least $85\%$ on the exam? The final Answer is 425
 ### Proof
 Since the exam grade is the percentage of words I recall correctly, we can set up a proportion to find the minimum number of words I need to learn: \begin{align} \frac{\text{number of words I need to learn}}{\text{total words}}&=\frac{85\%}{100\%}\\
 \frac{x}{500}&=\frac{85}{100}\\ x&=\frac{85}{100}\cdot 500\\ x&=85\cdot 5\\ x&=\boxed{425}. \end{align}Learning 425 words will lead to a score of exactly $85\%$, so I do not need to learn any more words than 425.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_words :: real and recall_percentage :: real and exam_grade :: real
assumes h0 : "total_words = 500"
and h1 : "recall_percentage = 0.85"
and h2 : "exam_grade = total_words * recall_percentage"
shows  "exam_grade >= 425"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: "If a student correctly recalls 85% of the 500 words they studied, is their exam grade at least 425?"

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes total_words :: int and recalled_words :: int and percentage :: real
assumes h0 : "total_words = 500"
and h1 : "percentage = recalled_words / total_words"
and h2 : "percentage >= 0.85"
shows  "recalled_words >= 425"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 I need to learn vocabulary words for my Spanish exam. There are 500 words and the exam grade is the percentage of these words that I recall correctly. Assuming I will recall correctly the words I learn and assuming my guesses will not yield any points, what is the least number of words I should learn to get at least $85\%$ on the exam? The final Answer is 425
 ### Proof
 Since the exam grade is the percentage of words I recall correctly, we can set up a proportion to find the minimum number of words I need to learn: \begin{align} \frac{\text{number of words I need to learn}}{\text{total words}}&=\frac{85\%}{100\%}\\
 \frac{x}{500}&=\frac{85}{100}\\ x&=\frac{85}{100}\cdot 500\\ x&=85\cdot 5\\ x&=\boxed{425}. \end{align}Learning 425 words will lead to a score of exactly $85\%$, so I do not need to learn any more words than 425.
 *)

theorem
fixes total_words :: int and recalled_words :: int and percentage :: real
assumes h0 : "total_words = 500"
and h1 : "percentage = recalled_words / total_words"
and h2 : "percentage >= 0.85"
shows  "recalled_words >= 425"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: If someone recalls at least 85% of 500 words they studied, how many words have they remembered at a minimum? The final answer is 425.
